title: How to become rich in the span of 2 years - Quora

response.answer_text: Going Web Find the one thing you are passionate aboutStart a blog and write articlesYou are a graduate… use your research skills to find out everything on SEO/SEAChoose your preferred Social Media Platforms and post quality stuff!If you have a smartphone with a decent enough camera.. make some relevant vlogsGoing real estate Get Every side job you can find, and I mean every job..Look for run down apartments/houses store spaceLook at the market.. what is the average price… you are a graduate so you are smart enough to do a balanced approachBuy the place, fix it (use reliable contractors but do a lot of stuff yourself so you become experienced and stuff)Sell it at market value… reinvest in next projectsGoing personal Get a jobBuy 3 tailored suits, 3 pair of nice shoes and 3 sets of casual clothingNetwork yourself into a better jobRepeatIn short… you need to hustle… the greatest assets you have are your time and your drive and your effort.. having a good brain helps… Do more than the people around you do, work smarter.. And share it here… succes stories are always nice ;)

Carefully read The Wall Street Journal, carefully noting the reported developments, then utilizing the services of a proven financial advisor to make investments, balancing roughly 1/2 between no-load mutual funds with proven positive results over time, and 1/2 split evenly between blue chip stocks paying dividend percentages of at least 4.5%, and municipal bonds with double tax exempt dividends (meaning exempt from both federal and state taxes). Using current events to invest, with proper professional advice, is nothing new, but may people either don’t utilize current events for investment, OR, don’t utilize sound professional advice. Now, manage your expectations. A recently published definition of “rich”, is having at least $2.3 million in financial assets. It may prove impossible to get there in just two years, but you’ll be well on your way. Getting “rich” is not an accident (unless you win a big lottery), but rather, a planned, methodical approach, which also mandates the least possible amount of debt (probably, only a home mortgage).
